WorkItem.ClosedComment: Operating as Intended. Mastery doesn't actually have value until it hits a breakpoint. The Stat Graph shows this better than RSV's ever will. There is no fixing this unless he breaks the model to improperly show value for partial mastery.
WorkItem.Description: When viewing the relative stat values, mastery does not appear
WorkItem.Summary: [Moonkin] Mastery missing from relative stat values

Comments.Message: Working as intended.  Check the release notes; mastery only works in whole increments of Eclipse % (per the Elitist Jerks thread), and I put this "flooring" functionality into Rawr.  It broke the relative stat values graph, but I added a new graph to the Moonkin options panel so you could visually see the effect.
Is this implemented in the 4.0.20b release? If so -- I'm apparently a bone head since I can't spot it. If it is implemented in the code but not the release, then please disregard :)

Dopefish, could you tell me where that graph is?  I'm looking in 4.0.20.0b, and I couldn't find it.

All I see in the "moonkin specific" menu is Damage per Cast Time and Mana Gains By Source...

Thanks.

I looked at the source code and found it.  It in the "options" tab of the character pane (between buffs and boss handler),
under the button labeled "Display Stats Graph"

I still believe that the relative stat values chart is wrong.

I have 3.2% extra mastery (720 rating).  It says I need 86.76 rating to the next breakpoint in the mouseover tooltip.
There should be some value to that 3% mastery.  But I guess that's a question as to what this chart should display:
the incremental value of one more mastery (which makes sense for hit, esp hit capped) or the avg value of "a few more
mastery", such that hitting the next % would yield.

For my use case (feeding this into pawn, for a quick and dirty valuation of a piece of gear) I would need the avg
value, so that I could get a quick feel of the relative value of my secondary stats.

That's just the thing: It's been demonstrated that there is _no_ value unless you can get enough to hit the breakpoint.  Also, why can't you just use Rawr for a quick and dirty valuation of a piece of gear?
